dashboard.label: 4. Help SPL Common Commands
dashboard.description: Help using common SPL commands to perform searches

div.p: Table of Contents
Splunk has a very rich and extensive set of commands. This page will attempt to address some of the more commonly used Splunk commands.

The head command will return the first user defined set of results from a search. If just head is used, the default value is ten, or in other words the first ten results will come back. Additionally, an analyst can provide a number after the head command and that many results will be returned. Below is an example of head, with and without the user provided number.

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | head
index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | head 1

div.p: The head command is most commonly used when trying to explore the data to build a more complex query. For example, use | head 10 and then manipulate the SPL query until you have your more complicated query. There is no reason to manipulate manipulate millions of records when you can test your data on a small subset until you are happy with the results. Head is a key for improving development time and removing stress from the system during development

The stats command is the swiss army knife of Splunk commands. While most often used for grouping fields together by statistical methods, stats is far more powerful. Stats with a by statement will join multiple sourcetypes and logs into one log. It will not be attempted to explain in words how to use the stats command, but it is highly recommended that the following videos be watched to gain further insight into how to use the stats command.

ul.li: Count the number of logs by a field

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | stats count by src_ip

ul.li: Count the number of logs by multiple fields

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | stats count by src_ip, dest_ip

ul.li: Distinct count (or number of unique fields)

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | stats dc(src_ip)

ul.li: Get the average value of a field

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | stats avg(bytes_in)

ul.li: Finding a range

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype="lame_conn" | stats min(bytes_in) max(bytes_in) range(bytes_in)

ul.li: Finding mean and variance

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype="lame_conn" | stats mean(bytes_in) var(bytes_in)

ul.li: First and Last time a field was seen - this is an amazing query for anomaly detection

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype="lame_conn" | stats first(_time) last(_time) by src_ip

For example, use | head 10 and then manipulate the SPL query until you have your more complicated query. There is no reason to manipulate manipulate millions of records when you can test your data on a small subset until you are happy with the results. Head is a key for improving development time and removing stress from the system during development

The eval command, simply put creates new fields. The basic syntax is to declare a new field name and then state what its value is. So for example eval foo = "bar". The new field value's name is foo and the new assigned value is "bar". The value is put in double quotes because the value is a string. One could also do something like this eval foo = src_ip where src_ip is an existing field. When a new field is assigned to the value in an existing field, the value is NOT placed in double quotes. Below are examplse of using an eval statement.

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | eval foo = "bar"
index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | eval foo = src_ip

ol.li: The below query is a case statement. Basic syntax is case([condition],[value if condition met], [other condition], [other value], [else can be used by declaring 1=1], [else value]

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | eval foo = case(src_ip="10.1.1.1", "Field is equal to 10.1.1.1", 1=1, "Field is not equal to 10.1.1.1"

div.p: The fields command is used to display the fields that are called out in a table format instead of the default tabular output. Often fields and table are used interchangeably. It should be noted that fields is the preferred method because it does not send the data back to the search head. The more work that can be performed on the indexer, the better so unless using it on the last line of an SPL command use fields instead of table. Additionally a "-" can be used on table to remove fields from the list of fields that are being passed down the pipe.

ul.li: Return only the src_ip, dest_ip, and _time fields

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | fields src_ip, dest_ip, _time

ul.li: Return all fields EXCEPT src_ip, dest_ip, and _time

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | fields - src_ip, dest_ip, _time

div.p: The table command is used to display the fields that are called out in a table format instead of the default tabular output. Often fields and table are used interchangeably. It should be noted that fields is the preferred method because it does not send the data back to the search head. The more work that can be performed on the indexer, the better so unless using it on the last line of an SPL command use fields instead of table.

ul.li: Return only the src_ip, dest_ip, and _time fields

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | table src_ip, dest_ip, _time

div.p: The rename command is used to change the name of a field to a new name. The command is invoked by having the following syntax | rename [original_field1] as [new_field_name1], [original_field2 as new_field_name2] The following are common use cases for using the rename command:

ul.li: Rename a field to a more intuitive name for reporting purposes.

li.b: | rename src_ip as "Source IP", dest_ip as "Destination IP"

ul.li: Remove a period from a field name.

li.b: | rename id.orig_h as src_ip

ul.li: Subsearches and commands like appendcols match on fields that have the same name. This may require one or more fields to be renamed so they match the fields in the subsearch

li.b: [inputlookup | search ip=192.168.1.1. | rename ip as src_ip ]

For example, use | head 10 and then manipulate the SPL query until you have your more complicated query. There is no reason to manipulate manipulate millions of records when you can test your data on a small subset until you are happy with the results. Head is a key for improving development time and removing stress from the system during development

Technically all search commands are supposed to start with the search command, but splunk automatically adds the search command as the first thing in your spl code, so you don't have to write it. There are times where you can't filter out everything you want before the first pipe, but somewhere down the pipe, you need to filter out unwanted fields. The search command will allow you to do this. In the example below, the query is looking for all the logs where the src_ip exists in both the sourcetype lame_conn and lame_dns.

p.b: index=lame_training (sourcetype=lame_conn OR sourcetype=lame_dns) | stats count by src_ip | search sourcetype=2

div.p: You can also use the search command to do a subsearch of fields. While it not the most efficient query, this could be a use case for the search command using the lame script eventgen information. The analyst again wants to return only the lame_conn sourcetype logs that exist within the lame_dns sourcetype logs. *note the | fields - count must be used because without it, the sub search will return src_ip and a count field and lame_conn has a src_ip field, but it does not have a count field.

p.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn [search index=lame_training sourcetype=corelight_dns | stats count by src_ip | fields - count]

div.p: Splunk by default will return the results back to the screen in chronological order based off the _time field. The logs will be displayed from newest log to oldest. The sort command allows the changing of how the logs are sorted. An analyst uses the | sort command and then declares which field(s) should be sorted by. a dash / minus (-) can be used to switch from ascending to descending order.

ul.li: To sort by the amount of bytes_in in ascending order
index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | sort bytes_in
To sort by the amount of bytes_in in descending order
index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | sort - bytes_in
You can sort by more than one field, below query will sort by ports and then by bytes in.
index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | sort dest_port bytes_in

div.p: Many times, we are interested in finding the most common values available in a field. The top command in Splunk helps us achieve this. It further helps in finding the count and percentage of the frequency the values occur in the events.

ul.li: To see the most common 7 occuring src_ip and the percentage of the results use the following

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | top limit=7 src_ip

ul.li: To see the most common 7 occuring dest_ip grouped by src_ip and the percentage of the results use the following

li.b: index=Lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | top limit=7 dest_ip by src_ip

ul.li: You can toggle the percentage of and off with the showperc=t or showperc=f

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetyep=lame_conn | top limit=7 dest_ip showperc=f

div.p: The rare command is the same syntax as the top command, but instead of showing the most common values it shows the least occuring value. This is a great tool in an analyst toolbelt because often you will see the anomalies as the "rare" values.

We have chosen to add the Where command as something that can be "almost" used interchangeably with the search command. If using a inputlookup, use a search command. If using less than and greater than symbols, use where. For almost all other use cases you should probably use search, but where will probably work.

p.b: index=lame_training (sourcetype=lame_conn OR sourcetype=lame_dns) | stats count by src_ip | where sourcetype>1

div.p: The chart command and the stats command are nearly identical in syntax. The chart command is a transforming command that returns your results in a table format. The results can then be used to display the data as a chart, such as a column, line, area, or pie chart.

ul.li: A simple use of the chart command

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | chart count by src_ip

div.p: The time chart is a specialized form of the chart command, it will be by default use _time as a by field, you do not have to say by _time.

ul.li: Often you will want to choose how splunk will divide up the time and one of the easiest ways to do this is to your the bin command. The following command will show the lame_conn events that occurred each minute by the transport method

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | bin span=1m _time | timechart count by transport

ul.li: use the timewrap command to compare like time frames so set your search to look at the last month and use timewrap 1week or look at 7 days of material and use timewrap 1day

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | bin span=1m _time | timechart count by transport | timewrap 1week

div.p: The dedup command is used in many languages and it doesn't take people long to realized Splunk has a dedup command as well. It is L.A.M.E.'s recommendation that you NOT use it. There are limited use cases for the dedup command, but almost every time that an analyst wants to use a dedup command they will find that using stats command will do the same job and faster. Stats command does not require the raw logs to be sent to the Search Head and therefore the work is being done on the Indexer and will perform faster than the dedup command.

ul.li: Dedup on the the src_ip

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | dedup src_ip

ul.li: Using stats on the src_ip

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | dedup src_ip

ul.li: Dedup using multiple fields

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | dedup src_ip, dest_ip

ul.li: Stats using multiple fields

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | stats count by src_ip, dest_ip

ul.li: BONUS - What if you are using the dedup to get the last time occurence of a src_ip

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | stats last(_time) as _time by src_ip

ul.li: If you need all the fields to come back with the results use the follwoing

li.b: index=lame_training sourcetype=lame_conn | stats values(*) as * count by src_ip | fields - count
